chapterTitle: Financial Leverage and Capital Structure Policy

columns.text: In this problem, we will use the capital asset pricing model (CAPM) and the M&M Proposition II theorem to define the firm's beta equity.

A firm's beta refers to how it behaves relative to the market. A high beta, beta that is greater than $1.0$, means that the price of the firm has higher highs and lower lows than the market which means that it is more volatile. A beta that is less than $1.0$ means that the price of the firm's stock has smaller movement compared to the market, meaning it is less volatile.

The beta of the firm can be defined by both the capital asset pricing model (CAPM) and the M&M Proposition II theorem since it assumes that the tax rate is zero. 

The capital asset pricing model (CAPM) is used to solve for the expected return on equity. This can be solved using this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{R}_{E}&=\beta_{E}\times(\text{R}_M-\text{R}_f)+\text{R}_f
\end{aligned}$$

Where,
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{R}_E&=\text{Return on equity}\\
\beta_E&=\text{Beta equity}\\
\text{R}_M&=\text{Market risk}\\
\text{R}_f&=\text{Risk-free rate}
\end{aligned}$$

As we can see from the formula above, it uses the beta equity to solve for the return on equity.

We can then look at the formula for the M&M Proposition II which is a model that solves for the firm's cost on equity by assuming a model that does not have taxes. The formula for this is:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{R}_E&=\text{R}_U+(\text{R}_U-\text{R}_D)\times\dfrac{\text{D}}{\text{E}}\times (1-\text{T}_c)
\end{aligned}$$

Where, 

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{R}_E&=\text{Levered cost of equity}\\
\text{R}_U&=\text{Unlevered cost of equity}\\
\text{R}_D&=\text{Cost of debt}\\
\dfrac{\text{D}}{\text{E}}&=\text{Debt-equity ratio}\\
\text{T}_c&=\text{Corporate tax rate}
\end{aligned}$$

We should also take note of the formula for the beta equity relative to the beta assets.

$$\begin{aligned}
\beta_E&=\beta_A\times\left(1+\dfrac{\text{D}}{\text{E}}\right)
\end{aligned}$$

We can then equate the CAPM formula to the M&M Proposition II formula to prove the formula given in the problem which relates the equity beta to the asset beta as seen in Step 5.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{CAPM}&=\text{M\&M Proposition II}\\
\text{R}_f+\beta_A(\text{R}_M-\text{R}_f)\times\left(1+\dfrac{\text{D}}{\text{E}}\right)&=\beta_E(\text{R}_M-\text{R}_f)+\text{R}_f
\end{aligned}$$

We can then cancel the risk-free rate since it appears in both sides of the equation. We will then be left with:

$$\begin{aligned}
\beta_A(\text{R}_M-\text{R}_f)\times\left(1+\dfrac{\text{D}}{\text{E}}\right)&=\beta_E(\text{R}_M-\text{R}_f)
\end{aligned}$$

We can then divide both sides by $(\text{R}_M-\text{R}_f)$ to cancel these on both sides.

$$\begin{aligned}
\dfrac{\beta_A(\text{R}_M-\text{R}_f)\times\left(1+\dfrac{\text{D}}{\text{E}}\right)}{(\text{R}_M-\text{R}_f)}&=\dfrac{\beta_E(\text{R}_M-\text{R}_f)}{(\text{R}_M-\text{R}_f)}\\[15 pt]
\beta_A\times\left(1+\dfrac{\text{D}}{\text{E}}\right)&=\beta_E
\end{aligned}$$

Flipping the equation, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\beta_E&=\beta_A\times \left(1+\dfrac{\text{D}}{\text{E}}\right)
\end{aligned}$$

Which proves that beta equity is related to beta assets by multiplying 1 plus the debt-equity ratio to the beta asset.
